awd_titl_txt: Surface Energy Balance on West Antarctica and the Ross Ice Shelf
awd_abstract_narration:
Atmospheric warming has been a major factor in the loss of ice shelves on the Antarctic Peninsula. In West Antarctica, oceanic warming is presently regarded as the largest source of stress on both the ice-shelves and at the grounding lines of the ice sheets. The loss of ice shelf buttressing and grounding line retreat may have already induced irreversible loss of Thwaites Glacier. To advance predictive models more data is needed regarding both water-induced fracturing on an ice shelf and  marine ice cliff instability near the grounding line. This project will help advance understanding of atmospheric circulation and solar radiation  over West Antarctica and the Ross Ice Shelf that lead to surface melting. In support of this project, and incorporating Antarctic science from this work, UCSD educators will sponsor a workshop series for exemplary middle and/or high school science teachers designed to address this need. Teacher participants will be carefully selected for their demonstrated leadership skills and will eventually become part of an cadre of "master" science teachers who will serve as local leaders in disseminating strategies and tools for addressing the NGSS (Ca Next Gen. of Sci. Eng. Stds.) to teachers throughout the county.

For the summer field seasons requested, UCSD scientists will deploy a suite instruments to measure downwelling and net shortwave and longwave fluxes, sensible and latent heat fluxes, and near-surface meteorology. This suite of instruments will be self-reliant with power requirements and will be supportable in the field with a single Twin Otter aircraft. The investigators plan to deploy this suite as a remote ice camp with a field party of 2-3 personnel, making measurements for at up to one month during each of the sampled summer field seasons. These measurements will be analyzed and interpreted to determine mesoscale conditions that govern surface melt in West Antarctica, in the context of improving coupled climate model parameterizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is related to the role of West Antarctic Ice Sheet loss in global sea level rise. Specifically, the floating ice shelves buttress the great ice sheets against more rapid outflow, yet these ice shelves are susceptible to mechanical degradation from atmospheric stress in a warming climate. Climate change projections anticipate more frequent warm air episodes over West Antarctica that cause surface melt and weakening of the ice shelves. To make reliable projections of ice shelf loss or resilience, climate models must be able to accurately simulate the surface energy balance (SEB) that governs whether the ice shelf surface will remain frozen or will melt for some period of time. The SEB has the largest contributions from solar radiation and atmospheric thermal infrared radiation, both of which are strongly influenced by pervasive cloud cover over Antarctica. The contributions from heat conduction between the atmosphere and surface (sensible heat flux), and energy exchange from transitions between liquid water and ice (latent heat flux), collectively known as the turbulent fluxes, are also important in the SEB.

 

Climate models often perform inaccurately over Antarctica, due to inaccuracies in complex processes such as the formation and dissipation of clouds made up of both liquid water droplets and various types of ice particles. For example, if cloud lifetime and transmissivity to solar radiation are not simulated accurately, the model will produce an inaccurate SEB that will be useless for projecting stress on the ice shelves. There is presently a scarcity of state-of-the-art atmospheric data that can validate the models and suggest improvements. The objective of this project was to collect such a data set, from a very remote Antarctic location having meteorology relevant to the SEB over West Antarctic Ice Shelves. The location was Siple Dome (81.65 S, 148.81 W), the site of a U.S. Antarctic Program summer field camp, and our measurement program spanned 21 December 2019 to 19 January 2020.

 

We deployed pyranometers and pyrgeometers, which are instruments that measure the solar and atmospheric thermal radiation reaching the surface. We deployed a sonic anemometer system that measured the turbulent fluxes. To help understand the variability in these SEB components, we deployed an atmospheric visible- and near-infrared-wavelength spectroradiometer that provides information about key cloud properties such as the presence of liquid versus ice water, cloud particle or liquid droplet size ranges, and the overall transmissivity of a cloud deck to atmospheric radiation. We also deployed a digital all-sky camera to record the fraction of the sky covered by clouds. With this suite of instruments we can understand how atmospheric variability affects the SEB with sufficient detail to evaluate current climate models and suggest improvements. For example, the spectroradiometer data show a diurnal cycle in cloud properties throughout several days, in which relatively thick clouds arrive over the field camp in early morning, gradually precipitate with snowfall, and by late afternoon become thin and mainly liquid water clouds. Current climate models cannot replicate this time evolution in Antarctic clouds.

 

The data set has been archived at the U.S. Antarctic Program Data Center (USAP-DC). The data are already being used by NASA Langley Research Center to help evaluate satellite atmospheric remote sensing products, which, like climate models, have additional challenges over polar regions. We are publishing the data in a format to encourage use by the climate modeling community. This project involved one female graduate student in both Antarctic field work and completion of her M.S. thesis, and also involved two minority undergraduate students with the Scripps Undergraduate Research Fellows (SURF) program, an NSF-supported Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program.
